title: The Year We Learned to Read Signals
author: Hass Dhia
excerpt: From neural sensors to airline AI, 2025 was the year we finally started listening to what customers, brains, and markets have been trying to tell us. Or at least, that's the claim.
linkedinTeaser:
A neuroscience breakthrough just gave us the ability to see incoming signals between neurons. Something that was literally impossible before.

Business is claiming a similar shift. American Airlines says AI will understand natural customer questions. Travel platforms promise any brand can compete. Marketers learned consistency beats novelty.

But here's what the headlines miss:

• Natural language interfaces have been "the future" for a decade. Adoption is the hard part.

• "Automation frees humans for connection" often means "automation eliminates roles."

• No generative AI tool has solved consistency yet. That's not pessimism, it's the current reality.

The businesses that win might be the ones that learned to listen. Or they might be the ones that avoided the hype and focused on fundamentals.

The jury's still out.

linkedinOrgTeaser:
NEW ANALYSIS: The Year We Learned to Read Signals

From neural sensors to airline AI, 2025 was positioned as the year businesses finally started listening to customers.

But the reality is more nuanced:

• American Airlines betting on conversational AI. Whether travelers want to chat with bots instead of clicking filters remains to be seen.

• "Democratizing infrastructure" has been the pitch of 10,000 startups. Some succeeded. Most didn't.

• No generative AI tool has solved the consistency problem yet.

Three takeaways for operators:

1. Audit your listening systems. This is useful regardless of technology choices.

2. Be skeptical of "automation frees humans" claims. Sometimes it does. Sometimes it just means fewer humans.

3. Demand consistency from your tools, but know the limits before betting customer experience on it.
